content.html:
In this unit, students will:

  • simplify numeric and algebraic expressions using the laws of exponents and simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots
  • interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems and write exponential functions to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay
  • graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features
  • compare linear and exponential functions

To accomplish these unit-level learning goals, students will complete the following lessons and activities.

Lesson Number

Lesson Title

Associated TEKS

Unit 5, Section A Overview:  Looking at Growth and Decay

5.1

Properties of Exponents

A11(B) simplify numeric and algebraic expressions using the laws of exponents, including integral and rational exponents.

5.2

Rational Exponents

A9(A) determine the domain and range of exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) and represent the domain and range using inequalities

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems

A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems

5.3

Patterns of Growth

A9(A) determine the domain and range of exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) and represent the domain and range using inequalities

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems

A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

5.4

Representing Exponential Growth

A9(A) determine the domain and range of exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) and represent the domain and range using inequalities;

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems; A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay; A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

5.5

Understanding and Representing Exponential Decay

A9(A) determine the domain and range of exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) and represent the domain and range using inequalities

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems; A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay;

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

5.6

Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems; A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay;

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

5.7

Analyzing Graphs

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems; A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay;

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

Unit 5, Section A Quiz

Unit 5, Section B Overview: Exponential Functions

5.8

Exponential Situations as Functions

A9(A) determine the domain and range of exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) and represent the domain and range using inequalities

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems,

A9(E) write, using technology, exponential functions that provide a reasonable fit to data and make predictions for real-world problems.

5.9

Interpreting Exponential Functions

A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems,

A9(E) write, using technology, exponential functions that provide a reasonable fit to data and make predictions for real-world problems.

5.10

Looking at Rates of Change

A3(B) calculate the rate of change of a linear function represented tabularly, graphically, or algebraically in context of mathematical and real-world problems;

5.11

Modeling Exponential Behavior

A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay;

5.12

Reasoning about Exponential Graphs (Part 1)

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

5.13

Reasoning about Exponential Graphs (Part 2)

A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems; and

Unit 5, Section B Quiz

Unit 5, Section C Overview: Comparing Linear and Exponential Functions

5.14

Which One Changes Faster?

A3(B) calculate the rate of change of a linear function represented tabularly, graphically, or algebraically in context of mathematical and real-world problems;

5.15

Changes over Equal Intervals

A3(B) calculate the rate of change of a linear function represented tabularly, graphically, or algebraically in context of mathematical and real-world problems;
